posts.cooked: Hi guys, we plan to try double sided timing belts off-season. What’s the difference of them compared to normal belts and what should we be aware of when putting them into practice? We’re using vex pulleys now. Any suggestions are welcome.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
I’m going to ask the use case–should I assume you’re trying to reverse a pulley direction, say for an intake or shooter?

They’ll handle about like a normal belt. However, expect to need at least one idler in your setup to keep the belt from snagging its own teeth, and do bear in mind that minimum wrap applies to all pulleys that are driving something.

We plan to use it mainly for our shooter because compared to gears they are lighter and easier to get accelerated. But if it is some easy to maintain we’re using it on intake too. (Both shooter and intake are on the arm so we want to keep it light)

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Are you also using a flywheel on this by any chance?

There’s no point in reduction the rotational inertia of a system that’s had mass intentionally added to it.

Double sided timing belts can work, but I’d use gears over them, or even a belt and then a small gear pair to reverse the direction.

You have a point there. We’re using fly wheels after all… but I feel it weird because I think the fly wheels are already capable of storing enough rotational inertia which make gears more like a burden or so… (correct me if I’m wrong). Also, I have been wondering whether gears or timing belts have a higher efficiency.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
troy_dietz:

There’s no point in reduction the rotational inertia of a system that’s had mass intentionally added to it.

Unless you are trying to be more intentional with that mass. But if we are at the point of the pros/cons of reversing gears we are probably splitting hairs. The moment of inertia on a gear set isn’t as good as is it could be, but also isn’t horrible.

enc0unt3r:

Also, I have been wondering whether gears or timing belts have a higher efficiency

Efficiency wise, this probably comes down to how well you have implemented each in your design rather than theoretical peak efficiency.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: A while back, we used a two-sided belt one year when we used 3x 775’s to drive our shooter.  The motors were arranged in a “W” (a motor pinion in each crook).  The two outer ones (the bottom of the W) were fixed and the inner/upper one was on slots to make belt replacement easy.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
enc0unt3r:

Also, I have been wondering whether gears or timing belts have a higher efficiency

Timing belts are usually quoted as higher efficiency, but so many parameters play into that. FRC tolerances and design practices lend to belts working out better* - the infamous 0.003" gear space adder comes to mind. They are likely around 85-95% efficient in our applications. Then again, adding additional reversals to a belt will lower its efficiency over a standard two pulley arrangement.

I usually consider packaging and availability of components before efficiency.

*Assuming you don’t overload them…I see more stripped belts than toothless gears.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
troy_dietz:

I see more stripped belts than toothless gears

We’ve broken all three of gear-sets, belt+pulleys, and chain+sprockets.  Typically from shock-loads.  I If I was to guess, I’d say large steel gears are the most durable, but broken belts are easiest to replace.
